author: bridge-bot
content: <chfast> Catching with the recent date, even after modexp repricing there are still cases running at ~30mgps in Go. I've checked the FastExp in Erigon, but this is the same strategy as Go has been doing since 1.20. Any ideas how to solve this for Erigon/Geth?

author: .fjl
content: What kind of inputs are these?

author: .fjl
content: We have investigated this a bit last week, and the main issue is the following:

author: .fjl
content: Go stdlib has two paths for exp: a naive path which is squaring and dividing, and an optimized path with montgomery multiplication.

author: .fjl
content: The montgomery based path is taken for exponent > 64bit, and it's actually kind of OK performance wise

author: .fjl
content: So we tried to lower the threshold for entering the montgomery based path down to size of 8 bits and it seems like it still performs a bit better

author: bridge-bot
content: <chfast>

author: chfast
content: The modexp repricing EIP makes all values at least 32-byte long, so the small numbers are not a concern any more.

author: .fjl
content: So the top ones are the slowest?

author: .fjl
content: Can we get them as statetests?

author: .fjl
content: I don't know where to find these inputs, we need them as standalone statetest in order to work with them.

author: chfast
content: For modexp imputs we could be synced with EEST at https://github.com/ethereum/execution-spec-tests/blob/main/tests/zkevm/test_worst_compute.py#L804, but this is not in my direct control.

author: .fjl
content: could be synced?

author: .fjl
content: do you know which cases there correspond to your 'ModexPawel4' case?

author: .fjl
content: ahh, nvm, I found it
